question: How to Draw Boxing Gloves? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin by drawing an oval. This will help you to sketch the first glove. 2. 2. Use a curved line to enclose a rounded rectangular shape on top of the oval. This forms the wrist of the glove. 3. 3. Erase the oval from the wrist. Then, enclose a rectangle across the wrist. 4. 4. Erase one side of the oval. Use overlapping curved lines to form the glove's thumb and mitten. Use short curved lines to draw a starburst pattern at the point where the two lines meet. 5. 5. Draw a second oval overlapping the first glove. Erase as necessary. 6. 6. Erase the top of the oval and sketch in a rectangular shape with rounded corners. It should overlap the first glove, so erase as necessary. This forms the wrist of the glove. Then, enclose another rectangular shape within the first. Draw curved lines across the base of the glove to indicate the curvature of the material. 7. 7. Erase the side of the oval. Outline the thumb and mitten of the glove using two overlapping curved lines. Use shorter curved lines to draw a starburst pattern at the point where the two lines meet. Then, draw a curved line from the wrist to this junction, indicating a seam. 8. 8. Draw a circle above the gloves. This will form the hook from which the gloves hang. Draw a "U" shaped line above it. Below it, extend two curved lines and double them back upon themselves. Then, draw pairs of lines from the hook to each glove. This represents the string used to hang the gloves. 9. 9. Detail the glove. Draw curved lines across the wrist and side of the glove to indicate wrinkles and seams. 10. Color your boxing gloves. They are typically red.

question: How to draw a rocket ship? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin by drawing a curved line. This will form one side of the rocket ship. 2. 2. Draw another curved line mirroring the first. They should meet in a gentle curve on the top end, but they should not connect on the bottom end. This outlines the body, or fuselage, of the rocket. 3. 3. Enclose the open end of the rocket using a pair of straight lines. 4. 4. Band the nose cone with two pairs of curved parallel lines. 5. 5. Draw portholes, or small windows, along the side of the rocket. To do so, draw several circles of different sizes. 6. 6. Draw the rocket's fin. First, draw a straight line from the tail of the rocket to its middle. Then, draw curved lines downward from each end of the straight line. Allow the curved lines to meet at a gentle point. 7. 7. Erase guide lines from the fin. 8. 8. Draw the rocket's second fin. To do so, extend two curved lines from the top side of the rocket - one emerging from the middle of the ship, the other from its base. Allow the lines to meet at a gentle point. 9. 9. Draw the flames, called exhaust, coming from the rocket's nozzle, or base. Use a series of short curved lines that meet in jagged points to draw a rounded triangular shape. Then, use another series of lines to draw a second layer. Finally, draw the third layer of the exhaust, allowing it to end at a point. 10. Color your rocket. Rockets such as the one in this drawing guide were popular illustrations during the 1950s and 1960s. Some were silver in color, while others had bright red, blue, or other colored markings.

question: How to make brownies? Provide illustrated steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Preheat your oven to 375ºF (190ºC). 2. Grease and line a 9×9 in. (23 x 23 cm.) baking tray about an inch deep. You can also line the pan with aluminum foil, if you like. If you don't have anything to line the tray with, grease the tray with butter and add a light layer of flour over. 3. Melt the butter or margarine in a small pan over low heat. While this is melting, complete the next two steps. It should take about a minute or two for the butter to melt. It'll melt faster if you start off with it at room temperature. 4. Mix the caster sugar and eggs in a separate bowl. Pour the sugar and eggs into a medium-sized bowl and stir the ingredients together until they're fully incorporated. This should take about a minute. You can use a wooden spoon, a whisk, or even an electric mixer to stir the ingredients together. 5. Mix the flour and chocolate powder together in a separate bowl. Now, pour these ingredients into a separate bowl and stir them until they are fully incorporated. 6. Pour the melted butter into the sugar and egg mixture. Then, stir until the butter is well mixed in. This will make a nice, light yellow, creamy mixture. 7. Sift in the cocoa mixture into the egg mixture a little at a time. Just pour the ingredients into a sieve and gently shake it to let the air in while the cocoa mixture falls down into the egg mixture. You can even lightly scrape a fork along the bottom of the sieve to help sift the cocoa mixture. 8. Add the chocolate chips into the mixture. Now, you can mix in the chocolate chips into the rest of the ingredients. You can use regular chocolate chips, or cute mini chips if you prefer that. If you're feeling adventurous and want to mix things up, you can also go for the white chocolate chips. [ citation needed ] 9. Pour the mixture into the baking tray. Now that the tray is greased, it should be all ready for you to pour in the mixture. Use a flat plastic mixer or knife to even out the mixture. It doesn't have to be perfectly even, but try to distribute it around the pan as evenly as you can so that the brownies are of even height throughout. [ citation needed ] 10. Insert the tray on the middle shelf of the oven and bake for 30 minutes. After 25 minutes, keep checking on the brownies to make sure they don't burn. You can even clean up while you're waiting for your brownies to cook. If you hang around the kitchen while the brownies begin to harden, you'll be craving this sweet treat even more! 11. Remove the brownies from the oven and let them cool. Wait at least five minutes for the brownies to cool. This will also give them time to harden a bit. If you cut into them when they're still cooling, it'll be harder to cut them cleanly. 12. Cut the brownies into bite-size chunks. You can cut tiny pieces, so you can devour them in one bite each. You can also cut larger brownies, so each portion is nice and hearty. It's up to you -- if you're making them for a large event, then the smaller, the better. But if you're just cooking for yourself and a few friends or family members, why not cut them to be a little bigger? You can even top them with confectioner's sugar for an extra sweet taste.

# Illustrated steps (image)

I created a simple 8-panel infographic that shows each stage, from prep to slicing.

*(Use/download the image above titled “Classic Brownies – Step by Step.”)*

# Text steps

## Ingredients (8-inch / 20 cm square pan; ~16 pieces)

* ½ cup (115 g) unsalted butter
* 1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar
* 2 large eggs
* 1 tsp vanilla extract
* ⅓ cup (35–40 g) unsweetened cocoa powder
* ½ cup (65 g) all-purpose flour
* ¼ tsp salt
* Optional: ¼ tsp baking powder (for cakier brownies)
* Optional mix-ins: ½ cup (85 g) chocolate chips or chopped nuts

## Equipment

8-inch square pan, parchment, medium saucepan,
    2 bowls, whisk, spatula.

## Steps

1. Prep
   Heat oven to **350°F / 175°C**. Line pan with parchment, leaving overhang.

2. Melt
   In a saucepan over low heat, melt **butter**. Stir in **sugar** until glossy and warm (about 1–2 min). Remove from heat; cool 2–3 min until just warm.

3. Whisk wet
   Whisk in **eggs** one at a time until smooth and shiny, then whisk in **vanilla**.

4. Combine dry
   In a bowl, whisk **flour, cocoa, salt** (and baking powder if using).

5. Make batter
   Stir dry ingredients into the warm butter-egg mixture just until no dry spots remain. Fold in **chocolate chips/nuts** if using. Batter will be thick.

6. Pan
   Scrape batter into the lined pan and smooth the top.

7. Bake
   Bake **20–25 min** (fudgy) until the edges are set and a toothpick in the center comes out with a few moist crumbs (not wet batter).

8. Cool & slice
   Cool in the pan on a rack **at least 20–30 min**. Lift out with parchment and slice into squares.

## Tips

* For extra fudgy: bake toward **20–22 min**, skip baking powder.
* For cakier: bake to **25–28 min** and include baking powder.
* Shiny top trick: make sure the sugar fully dissolves into the warm butter and whisk the eggs well.
* Storage: airtight at room temp **3–4 days**, or freeze up to **2 months** (wrap tightly).

question: How to change a flat tire safely on the roadside? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Find a safe area where traffic won’t be a risk. If you are near a road, park as far from traffic as possible and turn on your emergency hazard lights. Don’t park on an incline to keep your vehicle from rolling away, and stay off of soft soil or grass. If you have to drive slowly for a block or two to get to a safe, flat area, then so be it.Examples of safe areas are as follows: The shoulder of the highway, a public parking lot, or a large space with no pedestrian activity. Apply the parking brake once you’re parked to ensure the vehicle doesn’t move. For added peace of mind, place heavy rocks or blocks around each tire you aren’t changing to keep the vehicle from rolling. 2. The spare will likely be underneath a cover in the trunk. Every make and model will be a little bit different, but your spare should be under the cloth or plastic cover at the bottom of your trunk. Retrieve the wheel from the trunk. Also, remove the jack and the tire iron you need to remove the lug nuts. The tools for completing the change - including the jack, and lug wrench - will be located near the spare tire. On most vehicles, the tire iron is part of the jack. You’ll use it to turn the bolt on the end of the jack to raise or lower it, and also to remove the lug nuts on the tire. If you drive a Jeep or a large SUV, the spare tire may be on the outside or underneath the vehicle. If you don’t have a spare, your vehicle may have a sealant kit to temporarily patch your flat tire . If you don’t have that either, call a tow truck. 3. Move around your vehicle and check for any damaged components or wheels. This article focuses on replacing damaged tires - be sure to contact roadside services in the event you are experiencing any issues you cannot safely handle yourself either due to lack of experience, tools, replacement parts, or severity of the damage. 4. Provided you have the tools necessary, find a solid point on the frame of your vehicle to elevate the portion of the car near the wheel you need to replace. Remember to place the jack in a position that won't be hit by yourself or others, risking the vehicle being dropped from the jack. Elevate the vehicle until the tire is no longer touching the ground (recommended 1-2 inches) Place the jack on a part of the frame that will not damage or warp components of your vehicle, causing more damage. Begin to lift the vehicle by pressing down on the floor jack or by turning the floor jack handle slowly. You will begin to see the tires lift from the ground. To have enough room to dismount the tire, you want to make sure that the tire is at least lifted 3-6 inches from off the ground. Grab your jack stands. These are used as a safety precaution so that the vehicle doesn't fall to the ground in case your floor jacks break or slip. The owner's manual will show you where to place them. To engage the jack stands, use the lever that is attached to them and line it up with the jack stand point (Usually indicated by an arrow engraved into the car) but only raise the stand to about an inch or two away from the jack stand point which is usually the frame of the car. CAREFULLY release the pressure from your floor jack so that the vehicle falls into place with the jack stands 5. Remove the hubcap and loosen the nuts part-way. Start with the lowest bolt and avoid causing damage to the undamaged bolts/lug nuts. Pry the hubcap off using the flat end of your tire iron or a flathead screwdriver. Do not remove the lug nuts entirely. Just use the end of the tire iron to loosen the nuts by turning them counterclockwise so that there’s no longer any resistance. You should be able to spin the nuts by hand, but they shouldn’t be so loose that they spin freely. By keeping the wheel on the ground when you first loosen the nuts, you'll make sure that you're turning the nuts instead of the wheel. Your tire iron may have different sizes of openings on each end. The correct end for the nut will slip easily onto it, but it won’t be so loose that it rattles. If your vehicle doesn’t have a hub cap, don’t worry about that part. If it does, your hub cap may have a center cap that needs to be unscrewed first. On some newer vehicles you need a special “key” to unlock one of the lug nuts as a theft prevention strategy. Look in your glove box and trunk for a special tool that’ll remove that unique lug nut. These lug nuts will have a unique groove inside of them. Use the key to remove the locking lug nut. Keep all bolts as you will be using them to connect your spare tire to your car. 6. Place the divot in the jack directly under the metal rim of the frame. Get on the ground and use the flashlight on your phone to take a closer look. Touch the area directly behind the metal body of your exterior to feel and look for a thin, metal length. This is your frame. Set the jack underneath the frame right next to the tire you’re replacing. Many cars have molded plastic along the bottom. If you don't place the jack in the right spot, it will crack the plastic when you start lifting. If you're not sure about the right place to put the jack, read your owner's manual. There may be a small notch or mark just behind the front wheel wells, or in front of the rear wheel wells where the jack is intended to be placed. 7. Use the jack to raise your tire 4–6 inches (10–15 cm) off of the ground. Turn the handle of the jack clockwise to begin raising the platform up. Once the platform on the jack makes contact with the vehicle, take a look at the point where the jack meets the frame to confirm it’s on your frame. If it isn’t, loosen the jack and reposition it. If it is, continue to lift your vehicle off the ground . The vast majority of jacks are scissor jacks. You use the tire iron or a rod to twist the nut on the side and hoist the vehicle. You might have a pump-assisted jack, though. With a pump jack, you repeatedly move the handle up and down to raise the vehicle hydraulically. This can be kind of freaky the first time you do it. You might think your jack is going to snap or your car is going to tilt over. Don’t worry! Your jack and vehicle are designed to handle this. It can take a few minutes and a lot of elbow grease to get that vehicle up, so feel free to take breaks if you need to. It’s worth double-checking to make sure the jack is on the frame. You really don’t want to damage your vehicle with the jack. Make sure the vehicle is secure in the air by pressing down on the side of the vehicle that is jacked up in the air. Next, you need to add some wheel chalks to the opposite side wheels of the vehicle. If you have the car jacked from the front left side of the vehicle, then you would want to place two wheel-chocks under the rear tires to prevent the vehicle from rolling. 8. Pop the nuts off by hand and pull the tire off. You already loosened the nuts, so removing them should be fairly easy. Use the tire iron and brace the tire with your non-dominant hand if you need to. With all of the lug nuts removed, slide your busted wheel off of the axle and set it aside. Flip your hubcap upside down to turn it into a small bowl and set your lug nuts inside so that you don’t lose them. Use the proper body mechanics when dismounting a tire. Mounting and dismounting a tire is very tiresome and heavy on your back so you always want to make sure you squat using your legs with your back straight. Never place your legs under the vehicle while it's lifted up because that's a safety hazard. If you can, grab a small mechanics chair as this will help secure your back. 9. The side of the spare with the valve stem on it faces out. Line the lug nut bolts up with the openings on the spare and slide the spare on to the axle - holding the tires at the positions of 4 and 8, lifting the tire slightly and pulling the tire out. The valve stem is the little rubber pipe that sticks out where you add air to the tire. If it’s pointed inward towards the body of the vehicle, the tire is backwards. Fun fact, the spare tire is also known as a “donut.” Take one of the bolts you removed from the old tire, take your spare tire, and align the sockets on the tire rim with the sockets on the tire mount, then place the tire on the mount. Insert the bolt into the topmost socket and rotate the bolt into its socket enough to ensure the tire will not fall off the mount, but not too tightly as to fully insert the bolt into the socket. Grab the tire using proper body mechanics (this is important for your physical health) by getting down on one knee and rolling the tire onto your foot. Carefully lift with your arms and foot to align the tire with the hub. Align the tire with the wheel hub. Press the tire and wheel against the hub so that it sits completely flushed and symmetrical with the hub bearing (this is important for tightening reasons). Keep your foot pressed onto the tire to secure it. Begin screwing the lug nuts back on. First, you want to make sure that you're hub cap is securely placed back on. Start with one lug nut and thread it all the way down on the wheel stud to help hold the tire on the hub. 10. Don’t tighten the nuts using the tire iron just yet. Gently slide each over the bolt and tighten it by hand to partially lock them in place. You will tighten the lug nuts again once the car is down and there is no risk of it falling. Just to clarify, use the same lug nuts that were previously on your wheel. You don’t need special lug nuts for the spare. 11. With the wheel on the axle, lower the jack and remove it. Turn the handle or bolt on the jack counterclockwise to begin lowering the vehicle. Continue lowering the vehicle until the tire is comfortably back on the ground. Then, carefully remove the jack from underneath and set it back in your trunk. [8] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Keep your entire body out from underneath the vehicle. If the jack slips your vehicle gets closer to the ground, you don’t want your body underneath it. 12. Completely tighten the nuts until they won’t turn any further. Using the tire iron, tighten each nuts 3-4 times and then move on to the lug nut on the opposite side. Work in a star pattern to ensure the nuts are secured in an even pattern. Continue tightening the nuts in a cycle until all of the lug nuts are completely secure. [9] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source After you’ve tightened each nut, try to tighten each nut one more time to ensure they’re as tight as they can possibly get. Put your busted tire in the trunk alongside the jack and tire iron. 13. Remove and release all of the jacks from the car. Start off by lifting the vehicle up from the jack stands by using the floor jacks. Do this to make sure you are able to remove the jack stands. Remove the jack stands from under the vehicle. Remove the old tire and wheel assembly. Release the pressure from the floor jack by slowly turning the lever to the left and you will start to see the vehicle slowly fall to the ground. Once the vehicle is fully on the ground. Remove the floor jack. Remove wheel chocks. 14. Keep your speed under 50 miles per hour (80 km/h) and don't go further than 50 miles (80 km). If your spare is a full-size tire (rather than a donut), you can drive the same way you normally would. Check your tire pressure and fill your spare with air as needed. This is especially important if the spare has been in your trunk for a while, since it may have leaked a little in storage. Small punctures can usually be repaired for $15-100. If the tire is not repairable, you may need to buy a replacement tire.

# Text: How to change a flat tire safely on the roadside

## Before you start (safety first)

* Pull well off the road onto flat, solid ground. If you can’t get fully out of traffic or it’s a blind curve, bridge, or narrow shoulder, **call roadside assistance** instead.
* Turn on **hazard lights**. Put on a **reflective vest** if you have one.
* Set the **parking brake** (and put the car in Park; manual: 1st gear or Reverse).
* Place **wheel chocks**/big stones **on both sides** of a tire opposite the flat (e.g., if front-left is flat, chock the right-rear).
* Get people and pets away from the traffic side. Never crawl under the vehicle.

## Tools you’ll need

* Spare tire (compact “donut” or full-size)
* Jack and **owner’s-manual jack point locations**
* Lug wrench (and locking-lug key if you have one)
* Wheel chocks, gloves, flashlight, and warning triangle/cones (if available)

## Step-by-step

1. **Prep the area**
   Place a warning triangle 100–200 ft (30–60 m) behind the car if safe to do so.

2. **Expose the lugs**
   Remove the hubcap/wheel cover if present.

3. **Break the lug nuts loose**
   With the wheel **still on the ground**, use the lug wrench to loosen each nut about ½–1 turn. Push down with your foot if needed; don’t fully remove them yet.

4. **Position the jack at the correct jack point**
   Check your manual for the reinforced spot near the flat tire. Never jack on plastic trim or thin metal.

5. **Lift the vehicle**
   Raise until the flat tire just clears the ground by an inch or two (2–5 cm). Keep your body and limbs out from under the car.

6. **Remove the flat wheel**
   Spin off the loosened lug nuts and set them in a safe spot (a hubcap works). Pull the wheel straight off the hub.

7. **Mount the spare**
   Line up the holes with the studs; slide the wheel fully onto the hub. Thread the lug nuts **by hand** until snug.

8. **Initial tighten in a star pattern**
   Using the wrench, snug the nuts in a **star/ criss-cross** sequence—do not fully torque yet.

9. **Lower the vehicle and final tighten**
   Lower the car until the tire just contacts the ground and the jack is free. Now fully tighten the nuts in the **same star pattern** until firmly secure. (Later, torque to your vehicle’s spec.)

10. **Stow and check**
    Put the flat and tools away, remove chocks/triangle, and check the spare’s pressure. For compact spares, **observe the sidewall limits** (often around 50 mph / 80 km/h and short distances). Drive to a tire shop for repair or replacement **as soon as possible**.

question: How to Adjust Brightness on Windows 10 Using the Keyboard? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Find the appropriate keys on your keyboard. Windows 10 PCs allow you to adjust your brightness using hotkeys on your keyboard. These hotkeys are represented by two different images of a sun, one for increasing and another for decreasing brightness. Find the keys on your keyboard to get started. These hotkeys will look slightly different on every computer. They are often differentiated by a filled-in sun (decrease) and an empty sun (increase) or a sun with dots for rays (decrease) and a sun with lines for rays (increase). Also be on the lookout for arrows pointing upwards or downwards, indicating an increase or decrease in brightness. These hotkeys will be mapped onto different buttons on different keyboards. Check out your left and right arrow keys, or the function keys (F1, F2, etc.) lining the top of your keyboard. 2. Hold down the "Fn" key on your keyboard. The brightness hotkeys are not the primary function of the keys they are mapped onto. You'll therefore needed to hold down the Fn key while you adjust your screen's brightness. 3. Tap the appropriate hotkeys. While holding Fn , tap the corresponding hotkeys to turn your PC's brightness up or down.

* On **desktops/external monitors**, keyboard brightness keys usually won’t work—use the monitor’s buttons or its vendor app.

question: How can cars drive through a giant redwood tree at the Chandelier Tree in California? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: A large opening was carved through the base of the living Coast Redwood tree in the 1930s. While this was a popular tourist attraction, the practice of tunneling through giant trees is no longer done as it severely damages and weakens them.
generated_text:
Here’s the explanation (text), separate from the image above:

Cars can drive through the Chandelier Tree because a man-made tunnel was carved through the base of this very large coast redwood decades ago as a roadside attraction. The opening removes only a central portion of the trunk, leaving thick “legs” of wood on both sides. Like a stone arch, those side walls carry most of the compressive load down to the roots, so the trunk can still support itself.

Biologically, coast redwoods are unusually resilient: most water and nutrient transport happens in a thin, living layer just under the bark (the cambium and outer sapwood). Even though the tunnel removes wood and bark at the opening, continuous living tissue remains around the sides and back of the trunk, so flow up and down the tree can continue. Redwood heartwood is rot-resistant and the species can compartmentalize wounds, helping the tree survive long term.

To protect it, the attraction limits traffic to small vehicles, one at a time and at very low speed, minimizing vibration and impact. Modern arborists would not create new “drive-through” trees today, but this one remains as a historic curiosity—surviving thanks to the combination of clever arch-like shaping and the redwood’s natural toughness.

question: How to do a squat with a Squat Rack? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Start with a low weight. The most important thing with squats is to have the correct form, so you shouldn't attempt weighted squats until you can perform body weight squats with perfect form. Start with a low weight — maybe just using the bar (which weighs 45lbs) — and slowly build yourself up to heavier weights as your squat technique and muscle strength improves. 2. Position the bar correctly. Set up the squat rack so the bar is slightly below shoulder level. Position the safety bars so they are low enough to allow you to squat down fully with the bar on your shoulders. When you're ready, duck under the bar and grip it widely with your palms facing forward. Rest the bar across your upper back (not your neck). If this feels uncomfortable for you, try using a bar pad. 3. Squat using the same technique as the body weight squat. Place your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, with your toes pointing slightly outwards. Hinge your hips and push your butt backwards until your hamstrings are parallel with the floor. Keep your chest up, your shoulders back and your eyes looking straight ahead. Remember to keep your back straight — this is especially important when you are squatting with heavy weights. Push out of the squat with your heels and don't let your knees cave in towards the center. If this happens, you may need to reduce your weight. 4. Inhale on the way down, exhale on the way back up. Breathing deeply is very important when squatting heavy weights. If you hold your breath you can become dizzy, nauseous or even blackout. Take a deep breath in as you squat down and exhale powerfully as you rise up. Maintaining this breathing pattern will give you the energy you need to keep going. If you're pushing yourself to get another few repetitions, don't be afraid to pause between repetitions to take a couple of deep breaths.

# Visual steps (image)

# Text steps (detailed)

1. Rack setup

* Set J-cups around mid-chest so the bar is ~1–2 in (2–5 cm) below shoulder height.
* Set safety pins just below your expected bottom depth (they should catch the bar if you fail without touching it during good reps).

2. Load & secure

* Load plates evenly and add collars. Clear the area behind you.

3. Bar position & grip

* Walk under the bar. Place it across the upper traps (high-bar) or slightly lower on the rear delts (low-bar)—choose one and keep it consistent.
* Hands just outside shoulder width, squeeze the bar, wrists neutral (not bent back), elbows angled down/back to lock the upper back.

4. Stance & bracing

* Step under the bar with feet under hips, stand tall to unrack.
* Take 1–2 controlled steps back.
* Set feet shoulder-width (give or take), toes turned out ~10–30°.
* Big breath into your belly and sides, brace your core 360°, ribs stacked over pelvis.

5. The descent

* Keep the bar over your mid-foot.
* Break at hips and knees together; let the knees track over your toes (not collapsing inward).
* Maintain a neutral spine and steady gaze (chin tucked, eyes forward).

6. Bottom position & depth

* Aim for hip crease at or just below the top of the knee (or the deepest pain-free, controlled range you can maintain).
* Shins roughly forward, whole foot glued to the floor, weight mid-foot to heel.

7. The ascent

* Drive the floor away, push up through mid-foot/heels.
* Keep knees tracking over toes and chest tall; think “stand up with the bar” and “drive hips and chest together.”
* Exhale through the sticking point or finish the rep, then reset your breath between reps.

8. Re-rack safely

* Step forward until both sides touch the uprights, then sit the bar straight down into the J-cups.
* Don’t let go until you’re sure it’s seated.

9. Safety & spotting tips

* Warm up with the empty bar, then small jumps.
* Shoes with firm, flat or lifting soles improve stability.
* Use a spotter for heavy sets (they should follow your torso and assist only if the bar stalls).
* If you must bail alone: drop to the safeties by sitting back/soft knees and letting the bar settle on the pins—then step forward out.

10. Common mistakes to avoid

* Knees caving in hard.
* Heels lifting or rocking to toes.
* Bar drifting forward of mid-foot.
* Over-arching or rounding the back.
* Rushing the walkout (take only 1–2 steps).

11. Simple programming starter

* 3–5 sets × 3–8 reps, leaving 1–3 reps in reserve. Rest 2–4 minutes.

question: How to Do Free Squats? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Bend your knees. In essence, "squatting" simply means to bend your knees, bringing your backside closer to the floor. For best results, try bending your knees to a 90-degree angle, then standing back up. [1] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 2. Keep your knees behind your toes. This protects your knees and back and helps you achieve maximum results. When you move into a squat, bend your knees so that they move directly over your feet, without going further than your toes. [3] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 3. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart. For a standard free squat, start by keeping your feet under your shoulders. This help to avoid stress on your knees. 4. Angle your feet for plié squats. A plié squat is a free squat done with a wide stance. For these, it is important to angle your feet out and to bend your knees so they move directly over your feet. Begin by doing these at only a half-range of motion, and work up to getting your knee bends to 90 degrees. 5. Stop at the bottom. After you build up some leg strength, you may begin to "break 90," or allow your squat to deepen more than a 90-degree bend in your knees. However, it is important to stop when your thighs lightly come into contact with your calves. Going beyond this can place unnecessary stress on your knees.
generated_text:
# Free (Bodyweight) Squat — Text Guide

Follow these clear, safe steps. If anything hurts (sharp pain), stop and adjust range or seek a pro.

## 1) Set Your Stance

* Feet about shoulder-width apart (a little wider or narrower based on comfort).
* Toes turned slightly out (≈5–20°) so knees can track over them.
* Distribute weight through the whole foot (heel + big toe + little toe). Look ahead.

## 2) Brace

* Take a deep breath “360°” into your belly and sides.
* Gently lock ribs down as if prepping for a cough; keep spine neutral.
* Set shoulders down/back. Lightly squeeze glutes.

## 3) Initiate: Hips Back, Knees Out

* Start the squat by sending the hips slightly back, then let the knees bend.
* Let knees track in line with the toes (don’t cave inward).
* Reach your arms forward a bit for balance if helpful.

## 4) Descend Under Control

* Lower smoothly; keep chest proud and back neutral.
* Keep heels flat; stay balanced over mid-foot.
* Go as low as **your** mobility allows—aim for thighs parallel to the floor or lower without losing your brace.

## 5) Check the Bottom Position

* Knees track over toes; don’t collapse inward.
* Weight balanced (not on toes only; heels stay down).
* Avoid excessive pelvis tuck (“butt wink”). If it appears, stop just above that range.

## 6) Drive Up

* Push the floor away through mid-foot/heels.
* Stand up by extending hips and knees together (no shooting hips up first).
* Keep knees tracking over toes; exhale through the sticking point.

## 7) Finish Tall

* Stand tall with hips and knees fully extended.
* Reset your breath/bracing before the next rep.

---

## Breathing Cue (Simple)

* **Inhale & brace** before you descend → **exhale** as you drive up.
* For heavier sets, you can hold a gentle brace until you pass the hardest point, then exhale.

## Common Mistakes → Quick Fixes

* **Heels lift:** Widen stance slightly; slow down; work ankle mobility; try a small heel lift (5–10 mm).
* **Knees cave in:** Think “spread the floor” or “push knees toward pinky toes.”
* **Back rounds:** Re-brace; keep chest proud; shorten depth slightly; include core work.
* **Leaning too far forward:** Bring heels under hips; use counterbalance arms; keep gaze forward.
* **Bouncing/relaxing at bottom:** Pause briefly; keep tension.

## Regressions (Easier)

* **Box/Chair Squat:** Tap a box/chair behind you for depth control.
* **Supported Squat:** Hold a doorframe/TRX for assistance.
* **Heel-elevated Squat:** Place thin plates under heels to ease ankle demand.

## Helpful Progressions (Harder)

* **Goblet Squat (light weight)** for counterbalance and torso position.
* **Tempo Squat:** 3-sec lower, no bounce, smooth up.
* **Pause Squat:** 1–2 sec hold at the bottom with tension.
* **Split Squat / Pistol to Box** for single-leg control.

## Suggested Sets & Reps

* Beginners: **3 × 8–10 reps**, rest 60–90 s.
* Warm-up: 5 min light cardio + 2–3 easy ramp-up sets.

> Goal: Smooth, controlled reps with consistent depth and balance. Quality first; load later.

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
This diagram presents the pipeline of the proposed **StyleMaster**, which performs video stylization guided by a style image and a textual description.

The framework is composed of the following major components:

1. **Input & Output**:
   - The input is a raw video and a style image (e.g., Van Gogh painting).
   - The output is a stylized video with artistic consistency.

2. **Style Extraction**:
   - The style image is encoded using a **CLIP image encoder** to extract patch-level features and image embeddings.
   - Patches with lower similarity to the accompanying text prompt (e.g., "A lone penguin walks on a sandy beach at sunset.") are selected for style representation.
   - A local selection module (Q-Former) refines these patches.
   - A **global projection module** transforms them into global style tokens using contrastive learning, enhanced with specially constructed data pairs.

3. **Contrastive Dataset Construction**:
   - Positive pairs are created by rearranging anchor images.
   - Negative samples are synthesized via **model illusion** from arbitrary text-to-image models.

4. **Stylization Network (DiT Block)**:
   - A spatial-temporal diffusion transformer (DiT) applies multiple blocks of self-attention and cross-attention.
   - Style and text features are injected via decoupled cross-attention modules.
   - A motion adapter handles temporal consistency.

5. **Gray Tile ControlNet**:
   - Ensures better content preservation and stylization control.

Please generate:
 1. A visual diagram that clearly shows the pipeline from video and style image input to stylized video output.
 2. A separate caption summarizing the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: The pipeline of our proposed StyleMaster. We first obtain patch features and image embedding of the style image from CLIP, then we select the patches sharing less similarity with text prompt as texture guidance, and use a global projection module to transform it into global style descriptions. The global projection module is trained with a contrastive dataset constructed by model illusion through contrastive learning. The style information is then injected into the model through the decoupled cross-attention. The motion adapter and gray tile ControlNet are used to enhance dynamic quality and enable content control respectively.

A CLIP-based style extractor selects low text-aligned patches from the reference style image, refines them with a Q-Former, and projects them via contrastive learning into global style tokens trained with positives (rearranged anchors) and negatives (model-illusion samples). A spatial–temporal DiT injects text and style through decoupled cross-attention and a motion adapter for temporal consistency. A Gray Tile ControlNet conditions the diffusion to preserve content and control stylization, producing a coherent stylized video.

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
RISE-CoT is a reinforcement learning-driven closed-loop pipeline for generating high-quality Chains of Thought (CoTs) from image-annotation pairs. It operates in three steps: (1) Reasoning Generation, where VLMs produce CoTs that justify the given annotation using visual and contextual cues without directly leaking annotation details; (2) Annotation Reconstruction, where the annotation is reconstructed from the generated CoT to verify its sufficiency; (3) Consistency Validation, which defines a reward function to ensure logical independence, format compliance, and reconstruction accuracy. The outputs are high-quality CoTs paired with annotations and confidence scores, forming an enhanced dataset. This enriched dataset can then be used to fine-tune VLMs for interpretable and accurate reasoning in complex image annotation tasks.
Please generate:
	1.	A pipeline diagram showing the closed-loop flow: image + annotation → reasoning generation → annotation reconstruction → consistency validation → reward → enhanced dataset.
	2.	A separate caption summarizing the key idea of the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: Figure 1: RISE-CoT pipeline. The closed-loop framework generates high-quality, visually grounded CoTs by reasoning over image-annotation pairs, reconstructing annotations to validate reasoning, and filtering via consistency-based rewards. This process produces enhanced datasets for fine-tuning VLMs, improving both interpretability and annotation accuracy.

**Caption (text only):**
Overview of **RISE-CoT**, a reinforcement-learning, closed-loop pipeline for generating high-quality Chains of Thought (CoTs) from image–annotation pairs. A VLM first produces a CoT that explains the given annotation without leaking label details (Reasoning Generation). The CoT is then used to **reconstruct** the annotation to test sufficiency (Annotation Reconstruction). A **Consistency Validation** stage scores logical independence, format compliance, and reconstruction accuracy to produce a reward, which both filters data and updates the generator. The loop yields an **enhanced dataset** of *(image, annotation, CoT, confidence)* pairs for fine-tuning interpretable VLMs.

question: What are the main zones of the ocean and their characteristics? Provide an image and brief explanation.
reference_text: The ocean has pelagic and benthic realms. The pelagic includes epipelagic to hadopelagic zones. The habitat zones include Abyssal, Bathyal, Hadal, Neritic, and Oceanic, each with distinct light, pressure, and life conditions.
generated_text:
# Text (brief explanation)

**By depth/light (pelagic zones):**

* **Epipelagic (Sunlight, 0–200 m):** Bright light; photosynthesis; warm, well-mixed, oxygen-rich; most plankton and many fish.
* **Mesopelagic (Twilight, 200–1,000 m):** Dim light; no photosynthesis; strong temperature drop (thermocline) and an oxygen-minimum zone; daily vertical-migrating animals common.
* **Bathypelagic (Midnight, 1,000–4,000 m):** Total darkness; ~4 °C; high pressure; slow metabolisms; bioluminescence widespread (e.g., lanternfish, anglerfish).
* **Abyssopelagic (4,000–6,000 m):** Near-freezing; very high pressure; sparse, slow-growing life feeding on “marine snow.”
* **Hadalpelagic (6,000–11,000 m; trenches):** Isolated trench ecosystems; extreme pressure; specialized fauna (e.g., giant amphipods, snailfish).

**By distance from shore (horizontal):**

* **Intertidal/Littoral:** Shoreline area alternately exposed and submerged by tides; highly variable; barnacles, mussels, crabs, seaweeds.
* **Neritic (over continental shelf to ~200 m):** Well-lit, nutrient-rich, very productive; coral reefs, kelp forests; major fisheries.
* **Oceanic (beyond shelf):** Open-ocean waters; generally lower nutrients at the surface except where upwelling occurs; large pelagic species roam.

**Seafloor (benthic) counterparts:**

* **Sublittoral (Shelf seafloor, to ~200 m):** Seagrass beds, corals, diverse invertebrates.
* **Bathyal (200–4,000 m):** Continental slope; dark, cooler; soft sediments and canyon habitats.
* **Abyssal (4,000–6,000 m):** Vast plains; fine sediments; hydrothermal vents and cold seeps host chemosynthetic communities.
* **Hadal (6,000–11,000 m):** Trench floors and walls; scarce food, highly adapted species.

---

I created an infographic diagram showing these zones from shore to open ocean, with depth labels, light/temperature/pressure cues, and typical organisms.

question: What happens during alpha decay? Can you explain using the diagram?
reference_text: Alpha decay is when a heavy atom like Radium loses an alpha particle (2 protons and 2 neutrons), forming a new, lighter atom like Radon. The diagram shows how the mass and atomic number change.
generated_text:
# Text explanation (paired with the diagram above)

Alpha decay is when a heavy, unstable nucleus ejects an **alpha particle**—a tightly bound cluster of **2 protons + 2 neutrons** (a (^{4}_{2}\mathrm{He}) nucleus). This turns the original (parent) nucleus into a new (daughter) element.

**What the diagram shows:**

1. **Alpha cluster inside the parent.**
   For brief moments, a (2p+2n) cluster exists inside the nucleus.

2. **Quantum tunneling through the barrier.**
   The alpha is trapped by the strong nuclear force but pushed outward by Coulomb repulsion from the other protons. Its energy is **below** the top of the barrier, yet it can still escape by *tunneling* (inset potential curve).

3. **Transformation (notation).**
   [
   ^A_Z X ;\rightarrow; ^{A-4}_{Z-2} Y ;+; ^4_2\mathrm{He} ;+; Q
   ]

   * **Mass number (A)** drops by 4.
   * **Atomic number (Z)** drops by 2 (element changes).
   * (Q) is the released energy from the small mass difference.

4. **Energy and momentum sharing.**
   The (Q)-value appears mainly as the **kinetic energy of the alpha**, with a smaller **recoil** of the daughter nucleus; momenta are equal and opposite.

5. **Takeaway.**
   Alpha decay reduces a heavy nucleus to a slightly lighter one, emitting a helium-4 nucleus and energy; the escape happens via **quantum tunneling**, not by climbing over the barrier.

question: How are covalent bonds formed in a carbon dioxide molecule (CO₂)? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows the covalent bonds in a carbon dioxide molecule. A covalent bond is a chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms. The carbon dioxide molecule consists of two oxygen atoms and one carbon atom with the chemical formula of CO₂. At the outermost shell of the carbon atom, there are 4 electrons. Each oxygen atom shares 2 electrons with the carbon atom. So, it completes the outermost shell of the carbon atom with 8 total electrons.
generated_text:
# Written explanation

In CO₂, covalent bonds form by **sharing electron pairs** so that each atom reaches an octet:

* **Valence electrons:** Carbon has 4; each oxygen has 6.
* **Sharing to fill octets:** Carbon shares **two pairs** with each oxygen, creating **two C=O double bonds**. Each double bond consists of **one sigma (σ) bond** and **one pi (π) bond**.
* **How the σ bonds form:** Carbon **sp-hybridizes**, producing two linear sp orbitals 180° apart. Each sp orbital overlaps end-to-end with a hybrid orbital on an oxygen to form a σ bond.
* **How the π bonds form:** The unhybridized **p orbitals** on carbon and on each oxygen overlap **side-by-side**, making a π bond above and below the σ bond axis.
* **Geometry & lone pairs:** The sp hybridization gives the molecule a **linear** shape (O=C=O, 180°). Carbon has **no lone pairs**; each oxygen retains **two lone pairs**.
* **Result:** Two equivalent C=O double bonds hold the atoms together; although each C–O bond is polar, the molecule is **overall nonpolar** due to its linear symmetry.

(See the generated image above.)

question: I'm learning about self-supervised learning. How does SimSiam work without using negative pairs or momentum encoders? Please explain the architecture and training strategy with an image and short description.
reference_text: SimSiam is a minimalist self-supervised learning method that avoids both negative sample mining and momentum encoders. It uses two augmented views of the same image, processed by a shared encoder. One view passes through an additional predictor MLP, while the other applies stop-gradient to avoid representation collapse. The model maximizes similarity between the outputs without contrastive loss, relying only on architectural asymmetry to learn meaningful representations.
generated_text:
SimSiam is a self-supervised learning method that avoids using negative pairs or momentum encoders by relying on a simple architecture with two augmented views of the same image. The key idea is to use a Siamese network structure, where both augmented views are passed through separate encoders. The encoders produce representations of the images, which are then passed to a predictor (a small MLP) to generate predictions.

The critical component here is the "stop-gradient" operation applied to one of the branches, which prevents the gradients from propagating through it during backpropagation. This allows the model to learn by comparing the predictions of the two augmented views, pushing them to match without relying on negative samples.

In the training process, the model uses a loss function (usually cosine similarity) that minimizes the distance between the predictions from the two views.

reference_text: Doing a matrix multiplication and then adding a bias vector (left) is equivalent to adding a bias dimension with a constant of 1 to all input vectors and extending the weight matrix by 1 column - a bias column (right). Thus, if we preprocess our data by appending ones to all vectors we only have to learn a single matrix of weights instead of two matrices that hold the weights and the biases.

question: I'm trying to understand how Mask R-CNN works for instance segmentation. How does it extend Faster R-CNN to generate masks along with bounding boxes and class labels? Please include an image and brief explanation.
reference_text: Mask R-CNN extends Faster R-CNN by adding a parallel branch for predicting object masks in addition to bounding box and class predictions. After region proposals are extracted using a Region Proposal Network (RPN), features are aligned using RoIAlign (an improved version of RoIPool), and passed into two heads: one for classification and bounding box regression, and the other for per-pixel binary mask prediction. This design enables precise instance-level segmentation for each detected object.
